title: 2 Timothy 3:16, says 'All scripture is God breathed….' How can we trust the Bible when it says that it is the word of God? - Quora

response.answer_text: Don't let common Christian interpretation be your standard here. Consult a few scholarly commentaries and you'll get an entirely different perspective on what Paul was getting at here than what you've been getting from laypeople. The context of this verse is hard times, false teachers, and all of the things that come with those two harsh realities when proclaiming the gospel. This is a pastoral letter meant to address issues that Christians will face in both early and latter days of the faith. It is not an attempt to "prove the Bible by using the Bible". That's simply a cartoonish understanding of how to interpret the Bible and all things therein. Are we to believe that Paul thought his letters were eventually going to be published in what we call the New Testament canon? I don't. I think Paul believed that what he was teaching was divinely inspired and authoritative, but I don't think we can say that Paul thought he was writing Scripture. Paul is referring to the Old Testament. How do I know he's talking about the OT? He says so... in verse 15! It's pretty silly to then infer based upon a single verse without regard to context that Paul would reason that the Scriptures are God's word because they say they are. He wouldn't do that. He would likely appeal to various forms of argumentation. Paul was a Pharisee and a very well educated one at that. Paul had at least some training in rhetoric and knew very well how to persuade people with evidence. On what grounds *would* Paul petition someone to accept the truth of Christianity and the sacred writings that are seen as authoritative? Simple. The bodily resurrection of Jesus Christ. This is the central truth of the Christian faith. Just read his letters and this becomes quite clear. Read Acts 17 & 18. The truth of Christianity does not stand or fall on anything other than whether or not Jesus rose from the dead. By extension we can argue that the Bible and its authority as a witness of God's working in history are also ratified by Jesus' resurrection, or at least that it raises the probability of these documents being divinely inspired. Constructing a doctrine of inspiration, however, is not such a simple matter.

Point a microscope at the sky and all you will see is darkness. If you were to then conclude 'there are no stars' it would only be because your approach was wrong.   It is a circular argument. I think most rational Christians would agree with you.   I remember that my youth pastor made the same argument in a sermon.  "How do we know the Bible is God's word? Well... first because the Bible itself says so."  I sat in my chair and I cringed. As a 13 year old I knew that made no sense.  Maybe a better approach would be to actually consider: "Okay, the Bible claims it is the Word of God. It claims to be 'God breathed.' If that's true, how would I know it?"  So, do a test. If the Bible said: "Do 10 jumping jacks, turn around and touch the ground, and Jesus will appear to you." Then do it. If Jesus doesn't appear, you know the Bible isn't telling the truth.  But, the Bible doesn't say this. That would be ridiculous.   This is what it actually says:  "But if from there you seek the LORD your God, you will find him if you seek him with all your heart and with all your soul" - Deuteronomy 4:29  ""Ask and it will be given to you; seek and you will find; knock and the door will be opened to you." - Matthew 7:7  Jesus did not say: 'and maybe you will find.' He says you will. So, do what he says.  Make an honest prayer into the dark void of space. "God, if you are there, it is impossible for me to know it. In fact, everything I see seems to indicate that you do not exist. My logical mind tells me it is foolish even to make this prayer. Yet, this book, which claims to be your word, says I will find you if I seek you. It says your ways are higher than mine and your thoughts are higher than mine. If so, it is not possible for any human to know you unless you lower yourself to our level. This is my humble attempt. If you are there, I need to know."   If after a genuine effort, where you open yourself and your mind up to the possibility of God (even while remaining logical and skeptical) you do not find anything. Then I believe you have every right to say:  "I did what the Bible said, and I have concluded that it is not the Word of God, because it did not lead me to him." Edit: I want to add a few things to consider: "'WHOEVER WILL CALL ON THE NAME OF THE LORD WILL BE SAVED.' How then will they call on Him in whom they have not believed? How will they believe in Him whom they have not heard? And how will they hear without a preacher?" Romans 10:14 "So faith comes from hearing, and hearing through the word of Christ." Romans 10:17 ""Who is he, sir?" the man asked. "Tell me so that I may believe in him." John 9:36 "'How can I,' he said, 'unless someone explains it to me?' So he invited Philip to come up and sit with him." Acts 8:31

The book of 2nd Timothy, like every other book in the new testament, was written as a single volume of work. It was never intended for any kind of collective works as the Bible actually is. These singular works were epistles, letters to either the named recipient, or directed to a particular congregation. 2nd Timothy is actually Paul's second letter to Timothy, and not directed to any congregation, while Paul's letter to the Ephesians was directed to the congregation which was located at Ephasis. Knowing, then, that these are actually individual works, we have to phrase our questions individually. So now we have to ask, “What constitutes scripture?” It is obviously not referring to anyone who came around offering advice, and the Bible wouldn't exist for another 300 years, so it stands to reason that the scripture that he was tegerring to had to be Old Testament scriptute. The New Testament, however, is a completely different subject altogether. There is overwhelming evidence that much of the content in the Gospels was purposely altered by early Roman christian authorities to fit their own narrative, which in teturn allowed the introduction to so many non-Christians doctrines, practices, and entities into what is regarded as mainstream Christianity today. The molding of this new Christianity began when Rome legalized the practice of Christianity and ultimately made it the official religion of Rome in 313 ad with the Emperor Constantine’s Edict of Milan. We are told to study to showselves approved, rightly dividing the word of truth (2nd Timothy 3:15), and to PROVE all things (1st Thessalonians 5:21). While Grace is a gift of GOD, truth is something that you have to dig for… “It is the glory of God to conceal a thing: but the honour of kings is to search out a matter.” (Proverbs 25:2)

The Bible isn't a single work, it's a collection of men's writings over centuries and it has all the inaccuracies and contradictions you would expect from such a collection. It also has some beautiful passages and poetry.  The book that most helped me understand what the various writings in the Bible meant to the people it was written for was How to Read the Bible for all its Worth. It's not a debunking book, it's a book to help Christians better understand the book their faith is based on. Understanding in my case led to a huge sense of relief at not having to try to reconcile the irreconcilable any more. There really is an inversion here. You first need to trust the Bible. Only after that you may trust 2 Tim 3:16. But, how can you trust the Bible? I think it is much like you trust a friend. If your parents introduce you to an old friend and show they trust him very much, then you somehow inherit that trust. If you know somebody new, talk with her, do things together, do some favour, get a favour in return... If she proves trustworthy in small things, then you increase your trust, entrusts her with bigger things. After a while, she is your friend, or girlfriend, or even wife. Some people's relationship with the Bible grows like that. It's not a logical thing, it's a feeling. Jesus said, comparing himself to a shepherd: "his sheep follow him because they know his voice. But they will never follow a stranger; in fact, they will run away from him because they do not recognize a stranger’s voice.” John 10:4,5 NIV. I tried to follow this path, my that's not my thing. I'm kind of deaf to anything beyond reason and logic. Jesus seemed to be referring to this kind of people here: "I have other sheep that are not of this sheep pen. I must bring them also. They too will listen to my voice, and there shall be one flock and one shepherd." John 10:16 NIV. There are sheep not of this sheep pen, the one where those who "know his voice" are gathered. So, they don't know his voice, they don't recognize him. But, eventually, they will be brought to the fold. How? I think there is another way to trust the Bible. The one I'm treading now. I'm trying to destroy the Bible in the most honest way possible. I start with this hypothesis: There is a God that informed humanity of his existence through a message: the BibleA universe created by God operates in such a way that it's indistinguishable from a universe that simply is, without an intelligent cause. So, the only way to know for sure, apart from a direct manifestation, is the message -- if there is one. So, one must just refute the message, using a demonstration by reductio ad absurdum. You assume the message is from God, then it must be consistent with known facts (not theories or opinions) and self-consistent. Any contradiction refutes the hypothesis. Easy? Try to do it honestly. Try to trap the Bible like a DA traps a criminal in contradiction. But, have in mind that the hypothesis also postulates the existence of a God, an almighty agent. With that in mind, it is really hard to refute the Bible. One approach: the Bible says God never lies. So, how come God told Moses to tell a lie to pharaoh? "Tell pharaoh to let my people go on a 3 days' journey to offer sacrifices in the desert." It turns out this inconsistency is a clue to undestand the path of the exodus. A path that each reader of the account understands differently. I'm writing a book about it. Adam and Eve? See my answer here: Ricardo Almeida's answer to How has the Adam and Eve story been proven wrong?

In some sense, any worldview has to bottom out at an ultimate, axiomatic truth claim. For example, if I say that I will only trust those things that can be demonstrated by reason, I am left with the question of how do I know that I can trust reason. We may be able to reason through why we should trust our reason, after all there are very good reasons to depend on reason, but even then, we relied on reason to reach that conclusion. Descartes ran into this problem in his Meditations while trying to place his beliefs on sure footing. He recognized that there could be some powerful demon systematically deceiving him. Ultimately, he rejected this possibility, but it is noteworthy that it seems he relied upon a belief in the goodness of God to do so (a good God wouldn't allow him to be systematically deceived). Therefore, rather than prove that reason is trustworthy, we accept that as an axiom and go on to argue instead that doing so is a good way to live life and makes sense of the world around us. Our reasoning helps us to build safe buildings, planes that can fly, and allows us to come up with half-way decent way to govern ourselves. It works. It explains a wide range of phenomena. In a similar way, bottoming out the Christian worldview is a belief in the trustworthiness of God, and that God has revealed Himself through the Scriptures. Now, Christians can point to historical, archaeological, and textual evidence that they believe support these claims, but ultimately the Christian belief in the trustworthiness of scripture don't rest entirely on the findings of these fields. It can't, for Christians believe the authority of Scripture trumps the authority of the current opinion of any field of human knowledge. (If indeed Scripture is the Word of God, this is of course reasonable.) Of course, if the claim of Scripture's trustworthiness consistently ran against the findings of the full range of human knowledge and experience, than the Christian would be in a rather awkward position and had probably ought to consider constructing a worldview constructed from a new truth claim. Yet, at least for a couple billion of people over a couple thousand years, Scripture has appeared to be a reliable means to make sense of everything from history, science, human rights, and justice to one's personal experience of community, acceptance, forgiveness, and purpose. Not to mention Scripture's opening story of humanity made in the "image of God" allows one to solidly establish the claim of reason's trustworthiness as well, which is a real relief for those of us which value reason.

Paul was writing to a particular individual called Timothy who was a young minister and so the statement about scripture being God breathed was addressed to someone for the sake of encouragement. The early church’s structure was more akin to that of Brethrenism and Presbyterianism, in which there was a network of churches led by a ministry team, rather than the clerical hierarchy of Catholicism, Orthodoxy and Anglicanism, which was owes more to Roman pagan influences from Constantine onward. 2 Timothy is reckoned to be Paul’s last letter and so again we have to bear in mind he wasn’t writing for the sake of conversion. Another view is that 2 Timothy was written by a Pauline fan not that long after Paul’s death. At the end of the day as a Christian I believe it is an act of faith to take that step in recognizing Jesus as our lord and saviour and that simply going in for circular arguments with Atheists and the like is futile. 1 Peter 3:15 tells believers to give the reason for ‘our hope’, i.e. why do we believe in Jesus, when asked. Jesus also stated that by loving one another people around us would know we were his followers. It has often been Christians of the strongly fundamentalist (in the more modern sense of the term) who have gone in for the ‘because the bible says so’ and ‘the world is beautiful, therefore there must be a creator’ line. Most Atheists would have a rebuttal for those arguments and again the bible doesn’t encourage that approach.

2 Timothy 3:16, says "All scripture is God breathed…." How can we trust the Bible when it says that it is the word of God? I have seen many people use the 2 Timothy 3:16 passage to argue that the Bible is the word of God. It seems like a classic circular argumentThe Bible is the word of God, because the Bible says so. We should believe the Bible, because it is the word of God.  Obviously, an assertion in a book (unsupported by evidence) that the book is true and valid is meaningless. More to the point, what may be asserted in the holy book of a religion is meaningful to the followers of that religion, because they believe in the existence of the god that religion has grown up around. What the followers of that god, that religion, and the holy book about that god often fail to realize is that the book is meaningless to those who do not share their belief. They try to use the book, and the doctrine of the religion, as evidernce for their god, because they believe it. I am atheist. I have no belief in any god or gods. Having no such belief, I consider the religions that have grown up around verious gods to be nothing more than ancient folklore, no more meaningful than, say, Aesops fables.  In other words, the book doesn't matter to those who do not believe in whatever god the book is about.

If you believe god created the human brain, which gives us the ability to read and write, then shouldn’t god have those abilities? Secondly, even if he does exist you still have to prove he is the one that inspired it. Unfortunately, god is unavailable for answers.

Well, if it did say that, it would be Paul’s opinion. And then you would have to put it in the context of whatever else he wrote about scripture. And if it turned out to be a one-off extreme statement (as I think you might conclude) you would want to consider whether it has been correctly understood and indeed whether it is a late addition - a commentary by someone else that got included with the original text. Or you might consider that the Greek doesn’t actually say this. After all, it’s a bit odd for the man who rejected the laws of Moses to be making some blanket claim about the authority of “Scripture”! And indeed the Greek doesn’t say what you quote. It says something like “writings inspired by God also good for instruction”. There is no verb and it can be equally interpreted as “Any God-inspired writings are useful for your instruction”. Lastly, people seize upon “Scriptures”, as if somehow this verse pre-invents a modern Evangelical term for the old and new testaments, even before we had the New Testament! Nonsense. The word is simply the Greek equivalent of “writings”. I suggest that Paul had in mind the writings of himself and Peter and others in the church who were recording the life of Jesus or providing advice. That makes much more sense. And he would no doubt add the prophetic writings of the Old Testament, insofar as they foretold the New.

Experiment honestly casting aside all prejudice and bias, and you may just find the answer you’re looking for.

Catholics would say that we don’t need to trust the Bible as the Word of God on its own saying so. Rather, we can trust the Bible as a historical document when it describes Jesus and the Church—and we can look at the Church and see whether it is faithful to what was described, and then once we trust that the Church is guided by the Spirit (and it is very difficult to see how it could not be, given its history), then the Church can identify the Bible as inspired. This is, indeed, the historical way it was chosen, and how it still is backed. It also allows us to get around such problems as knowing what is or is not in the Bible—since the Bible never sets out what is inspired.
